channel.title: Book buying?
channel.description:
hey, im pretty new to java programming in general. i mean i've done some work with servers, but i want to understand java more then i already do. friend of mine suggested i buy this book on java programming for begginers, what do you guys think? what can i do to understand java more than just editting a server base?
~Thanks~
EDIT: unrelated lol but, why'd my rep go down, did someone rep-- me?

item.title: Book buying?
item.dc:creator: @Mod_Adam Adam
item.description:
@Mod_Adam wrote:

Well if you’ve already got a minuscule amount of knowledge (I.E. - The level after taking any Intro to Programming course in a University) I suggest buying a Data Structures book. Personally, I like Data Structures and Algorithms in Java Second Edition by Robert Lafore.

EDIT: With very little knowledge, I suggest purchasing Head First Java Second Edition by Kathy Sierra and Bert Bates.

Both of these books can be found on Amazon.

Read full topic

If you actually learn the language before jumping in I imagine it could be like any other source…

item.title: Book buying?
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

Natey:

It’s not aimed for starter programmers.

Correction. It’s not aimed for people who want everything handed to them.

item.title: Book buying?
item.dc:creator: @Ventrozip Ventrozip
item.description:
@Ventrozip wrote:

[quote=“the elve age, post:2, topic:338482”]Its a lame answer but.
Start on easy bases, such as iClarity, or Dev.

DON’T start on Hyperion.

Maybe 377d (its kind of easy)

Read java documentation,

http://leepoint.net/notes-java/ - best site i know.

Uncle Sam’s java book is great.[/quote]
Whats wrong with starting on Hyperion?

Read full topic
